comments.content:
Copying from gerrit of the proposed patch as I think is relevant and might get lost in the sea of reviews:

"""
Well the code in the patch looks good - but I don't think we should call the bug closed.

I think that a real bug here (and this is only IIUC and I may not) is that the only possible place instance can have no disk is if it's booted from an ISO AND has 0 specified as it's root GB.

There are several problems with this:

1) Specifying 0 in the flavor for disk size means we don't care, NOT no disk needed (see https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/89fd0770420200c58a20006eee3f3a03aa21fe37/nova/compute/api.py#L597). This is what libvirt and I assume xenapi do, and unless there is a clear benefit to this (I see none) - I'd change this first - this would make the bug go away in itself.

2) Raising a redefined exception is slightly better from the debugging perspective and I am sure admins will be thankfull for this patch, but form user point of view it's still bad (it fails, I have no idea why!) so if we are going to stick with this behavior for ISO - we should make sure it's prevented in the API then (we probably should not do this, but I am trying to illustrate a point here).

The real bug and the fix is imho here: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/89fd0770420200c58a20006eee3f3a03aa21fe37/nova/virt/vmwareapi/vmops.py#L496

"""
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ndipanov

comments.content: @Nikola - I do not agree. It is legitimate to run an instance that does not have a disk (as is the case here). If this is an iso - that may not require a disk then why do we need to create a disk? Unless I have misunderstood your assessment here.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~garyk

comments.content: Well maybe you do not need to - the real problem is that 0 size means whatever for libvirt and means something else for vmWare which is bad.
